com.sri.ai.expresso.helper

Class AbstractExpressionWrapper

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.sri.ai.grinder.core.AbstractExpression
      • com.sri.ai.expresso.helper.AbstractExpressionWrapper
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Expression, Serializable, Cloneable, Comparable<Object>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AbstractConstraint, DefaultMonomial, DefaultPolynomial, LazySampledFunction, RangeAndExceptionsSet.DefaultRangeAndExceptionsSet, RangeAndExceptionsSet.Empty, RangeAndExceptionsSet.Singleton, TrueContext

    @Beta
public abstract class AbstractExpressionWrapper
extends AbstractExpression
    A implementation of Expression that redirects methods to an inner Expression.

    To see why this is useful, consider the following:

    • Expression is an interface with many methods with relatively high complexity, so creating an implementation from scratch is labor-intensive;
    • Therefore, most implementations of Expression extend an existing (possible abstract) implementation. Currently, most implementations are extensions of AbstractExpression;
    • When creating a new implementation of Expression that may have varying syntactic forms, such as a boolean formula which can be either a function application of a boolean conjunctive, or a boolean constant, it is not possible to extend DefaultFunctionApplication or DefaultSymbol, because they are restricted to a single syntactic type;
    • Extending directly from AbstractExpression would require the re-implementation and functionality of duplication of those syntactic types, which would be highly undesirable;
    • The best solution is therefore to have the class extend AbstractExpressionWrapper and have its method getInnerExpression() provide an instance of an already existing implementation of Expression of the appropriate type.

    While Expression is an immutable type, extensions of this class are allowed to be mutable, as long as they are no longer changed after having being used as an Expression for the first time. This may be useful for efficiently setting up objects before releasing them for general use.

    Author:
    braz
    See Also:

      • getSyntacticFormType

        public Object getSyntacticFormType()
        Description copied from interface: Expression
        Indicates what syntactic form the expression is. Syntactic forms are the primitive types of expressions in a logic. For example, in FOL we have the forms: term, predicate, simple formula, quantified formula, etc. HOL typically has function applications and lambda expressions as its basic syntactic forms.

        public SyntaxTree getSyntaxTree()

      • replaceSymbol

        public Expression replaceSymbol(Expression symbol,
                                Expression newSymbol,
                                Registry registry)
        Description copied from interface: Expression
        Renames all occurrences of a symbol, including when it is declared. For example, renaming p by q in for all p(X) in People : happy(p(X)) results in for all q(X) in People : happy(q(X)).
        Returns:
        the result of renaming symbol as newSymbol everywhere in expression.

      • equals

        public boolean equals(Object anotherObject)
        Description copied from interface: Expression
        Indicates whether two expressions are syntactically equal, allowing comparisons to Strings as well as a convenience (this is equivalent to comparing to the Symbol obtained from the String). Note that the comparison to String violates the specification of equals, since s.equals(e) for s and e String and Expression respectively will always return false, even if e.equals(s) returns true. However, this should not be a problem if Strings and Expressions are not mixed in containers or algorithms relying on equals, which would not be possible even if the comparison to String convenience were omitted. TODO: In the future we may replace this convenience by a method specific to comparing to Strings, which would be more explicit. This will take some work as all invocations of equals on Strings would have to be replaced by this new method.
        Specified by:
        equals in interface Expression
        Overrides:
        equals in class AbstractExpression
        Parameters:
        anotherObject - the object to compare this expression to.
        Returns:
        whether the two objects are considered equal.

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class AbstractExpression

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Overridden in order to avoid using Expression's implementation, which would use the cached inner expression and not produce an update String if the instance changed (remember that instances to this class are allowed to change before being used as an expression for the first time). This implementation re-computes an Expression every time it is invoked.
        Overrides:
        toString in class AbstractExpression
